In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.

div.head: THE TURKS AND THEIR RULERS.
div.p: Saul also is amongst the prophets, and Ahmed Djelaleddin Pasha is amongst the reformers remarks the "Times" in comment upon the Pasha's now famous letters. The man who for long years was deep in the dark mysteries of Yildiz, who was the favourite and the counsellor of the Sultan, and who filled the responsible post of chief of His Majesty's political Cabinet, comes forward and testifies that there is no hope for Turkey but in a thorough reform of her administration, and that another reign like that of Abdul Hamid has become impossible. Ahmed Pasha, it need hardly be said, is a discarded favourite, and he does not live in Constantinople or in the immediate dominions of his Sovereign. If he b did, he would hardly have ventured to express the progressive and enlightened view which his letter to us contains. But, like many other Tarks who once basked in the favour of their master, he no longer finds the air of his native i land wholesome, and it is from Cairo that he t now proclaims his convictions. Their worth will be differently estimated. At Yildiz they will be represented as the outcome of vindict iveness In other circles they may perhaps be quoted, and with more justice, as the real opinions of a statesman who was made the victim of unscrupulous intriguers because, with generous imprudence, he dared to give unpalatable advice to an unteachable despot. We t shall not seek to appraise Ahmed Pasha's motives. It is enough to remark that few living men can have a more intimate knowledge of the character of Abdul Hamid's personal rule, or be in a better position to r judge of its effects upon the Turkish people 5 and the Turkish State. Ahmed Djelaleddin's interest has been excited by communications on the condition of Turkey which have lately appeared in our columns. He is impressed and gratified by the knowledge of Turkish t affairs which "Galata," and the author of d "The Unrest in Turkey " display, and still more by the sympathetic appreciation! with which they speak of the Turkish t people. He assumes quite rightly, as we believe, that this feeling is shared by large classes of Englishmen, and he assures us that the Tarks welcome these indications that the old friendship between the two nations survives the estrangement between their Governments which a wiser policy on both sides should have averted. We have no doubt that his statement of the attitude of his countrymen towards England is correct. Much in our policy and in our language has inevitably exasperated the Turkish mind, but there is plenty of evidence to show that in their hearts the Turkish people still believe in our justice and in our good will towards them. They know the great and growing importance of the distinc tion which we draw between them and their present rulers.

Loyalty, love of country, and respect for lawful authority, even when it is shamefully misused, are conspicuous features of the Turkish character. They are invaluable qualities in the character of any nation, and they are qualities which, as a race, we specially prize and admire. There is no sign that they are dying out in the most virile people of the Near PEast, but there are abundant signs that the universal misgovernment of the Palace has outraged them to the verge of endurance. Our correspondents have given manifold proofs of the existence of this feeling in different classes of the population and have insisted upon its political importance. They have shown that, outside of Macedonia, the position of the Musulman sabjects of the Sultan is hardly less intolerable than the position of his Christian subjects. is not Christians, but educated Mahomedans, who are the ordinary victims of the organized terrorism which prevails in the capital. It is their liberty and their safety which are imperilled by the frightful system of delation and corruption established in Constantinople. The poorer Mahomedans of the provinces fare no better. They are patight, to a fault, of corruption and of tyrann, but even the patience of the Turkish provincial has its limits. Since last year the Musulmans of at least three Anatolian towns have expelled by main force the Valis whom the Palace had set over them. The manner in which they drove out the oppressors is more suggestive than the expulsion itself. There was no disorderly rioting, no looting, and no destruction of property. The Valis were bidden to go, and no greater violence was employed than was needful to make them go. The people of Bitlis actually telegraphed to the Sultan and assured him that they were perfectly loyal, but that they would not have his Vali back. The incompar rable endurance and good humour of the Turkish soldier under hardship and privation are proverbial. Even he has been provoked to mutiny by the wanton wrongs inflicted on him; but it is very noteworthy that in almost all cases the revolted soldiers, like the revolted civilians, have displayed exemplary moderation and selfrestraint. At Beirut and at Uskub the towns were at their mercy. They insisted on compliance with their demands. In the one case they exacted the payment of arrears due to them, and in the other they obtained the dismissal to which they were lawfully entitled. In neither instance did they plunder or molest the civil population. They asked for their bare rights. When they had got those rights they went quietly home. Men who can act in that fashion have a strong claim to the measure of decent government they desire.

Discontent throughout the Ottoman Empire is bitter, it is growing, and it is well-founded. "Galata" contends that, on grounds both of justice and of expediency, it is entitled to the hearty sympathy and the strong moral support of the British nation, and, of course, Ahmed Djelaleddin, now that he is free from the trammels of office, openly adopts the same view. It is unfair and unwise, they argue, to fix our gaze upon the misgovernment of Macedonia and to ignore the almost equally grave misgovernment of the rest of Turkey. The plight of Macedonia is indeed worse than that of the other provinces, but, tto-day at any rate, the main reason why it is e worse is because not even the moral lectures k of the Balkan Committee can restrain the 1 Greeks, the Bulgarians, and the Servians of that region from the practice of "sheer massacre" for their private ends. But their s selfish ambitions, it is submitted, should not entitle them to the special consideration of 1 Europe. It is unwise to accord them, a privi- 1leged position, because that transforms the whole question of Turkish reform from a 1 question of justice into a question of creed. To do this is to play into Abdul Hamid's hands, by stimulating those feelings of Mahonedan exclusiveness which he sedulously cultivates throughout the world. It is to intensify the obstacles to reform in Macedonia, to retard the growth of the reform movement a in the rest of Turkey, and to foster amongst the Mahomedans of India of Egypt, and of the Sudan, as well as amongst their brethren of Turkey, the suspicion that, for all our protestations, we have one standard of justice for their faith and another for our own. There 1 is another direction in which British influence emight be exerted with advantage, to the benefit of the Sultan's subjects of all races and denominations, and, if he would only realize it, to the benefit of the Turkish State as a whole. The economic development of the country is perhaps the most crying of all its needs. Its impoverishment by the exactions of the Treasury and reckless finance is one of the main causes of the growing discontent and unrest. If the more progressive elements in Turkey were to apply themselves to promote economic improvements rather than to clamour for political changes which the present regime 1 will never, we fear, spontaneously concede, they might look, we feel sure, for a measure f of active support from Great Britain, which we are not in a position to give, whatever may be our sympathies, to the grievances of political malcontents, and which we certainly cannot give to dreams of vast political transformaetions, such as the revival of an Arab Empire.

div.head: The Egyptian University.
div.p: The Committee of the Egyptian University has emitted a strong appeal for funds.

div.head: Egyptian Mall Steamship Co.
div.p: The first run of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company is to be commenced on December 7 by the "Heliopolis."

div.head: A Pilgrim to Mecca.
div.p: It is understood that if Raisuilis proposals in regard to Sir Harry MacLean's ransom are accepted, he will make a pilgrimage to Mecca.

div.head: Minish New Station.
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways Administra tion requests us to again call the attention of the public to the fact that Minieh new station is now open.

div.head: Khedivial Law School.
div.p: Fifty pupils have been admitted to the English section of the Khedivial Law School and 28 applications refused. All candidates for the French sections were accepted.

div.head: A Fraudulent Pasha.
div.p: A Lyons paper reports the seizure of a large stock of jewellery at the Bellegarde frontier customs belonging to R... Pasha. The Pasha was fined to 2,000 francs.

div.head: Press Case.
div.p: "El Mokattam," "El-Watan" and "El-Shark" have decided to appeal to the Court of Cassa- tion from the judgment of the Cairo Tribunal of the 1st Instance, in the libel case brought against them by the Mamur of Karmuz.

div.head: Fires In Cairo.
div.p: Two fires broke out during the night of the 8th inst., one in the Sharia Hanzawa, and another in the Sharia Nubar Pasha. The fire brigade was quickly in attendance and no serious damage was done in either case.

div.head: Plot Boy In Paris.
div.p: At the French Academy of Medicine in Paris last week, M. Piot Bey, of Alexandria, reported that by serum treatment he had reduced bovine mortality in Egypt, notwithstanding frequent outbreaks of disease, to below 4 per cent.

div.head: The Khedive's Heis
div.p: The person, who is now travelling in the United States under the name of Prince Dabro of Egypt and who is styled by some of the American papers as the "Khedive's heir," is still enjoying himself. An American journal states that the Prince is going to Texas to study the cotton industry. The Prince confesses that he was amazed at the greatness of New York.

div.head: Colloquial Arabio.
div.p: What foreigners most need in this country is not so much literary Arabic but rather the language of the people. For this purpose the Berlitz Schools of Languages, 12 rue Rosette Alexandria and 1 Sharia Kamel. Cairo have inaugurated a special course of Arabic which in a short time gives pupils the essentials for understanding and making themselves under- stood without difficulty. (Advt.)

div.head: Disorderly Government Offlolals.
div.p: The "Misr" has received a lengthy letter from the Fayoum reporting that four Govern- ment officials entered the Fayoum hotel in an advanced state of inebriety and demanded drinks, which were refused. Thereupon they created a great disturbance. It is alleged that the local authorities are trying to hush the case up on account of the persons implicated being attached to the Government.

div.head: The Wisdom of Moderation.
div.p: In a leading article "Al Mokattam" exhorts the people of Egypt to be moderate in their demands and warns them not to try England too severely by exhibitions of foolish hatred such as are afforded by a section of the press. Our contemporary recalls the answer given on one occasion to the demands of Malta for constitutional rights when the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs pointed out that they could do nothing as long as the people showed irrational ill-feeling.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: A total of 590 births against 364 deaths are recorded m Cairo for the week ending October 7th. Eight Europeans are included in the former numbers, and thirteen in the latter, 11 of whom were adults, the remaining two being children under the age of 5 years. Of the specific diseases, diphtheria has claimed greater number of victims, nine persons, inc' iding three Europeans, having succumbed to it. There were also 7 deaths from typh s, 3 from typhoid, 1 from measles and 1 from puerperal fever..

div.head: EGYPTIAN FINANCE,
div.p: The following letter from the "Times" will be read with interest. We might, however, point out that the suggestion that the Go- vernment should authorise the National Bank to make a further issue of notes, tentatively, against approved securities lodged with European State Banks but without a deposit in gold, appears to us ultra vires the ar- ticles of association of the National Bank.

For ourselves we are content to leave the financial arrangements of the country in the hands of the advisers of the Govern- ment and the National Bank of Egypt who have served the country so well under the trying circumstances of the crisis.
"Sir, The Egyptian cotton crop promises to be a record one, in quantity not less that seven millions of cantars, and in value about 30 millions sterling.

"This is a fortunate circumstance. Over- speculation and over-trading, encouraged by a too liberal granting of credits to Egyptian firms by Europeans banks, have brought about their inevitable results-loss and discredit; but when this year's large cotton crop is con- verted into 30 millions sterling the present inoney stringency in Egypt will be relieved.

"Just as the European banks were too liberal in the past in facilitating Egyptian firms, so at the present they have become too rigid in withdrawing these facilities. The tendency in our age is to go from one extreme to an other. In consequence the coming Egyptian cotton campaign will be an arduous one for Alexandrian traders. Too liberally supplied in recent years with money from European credits, they were in the habit of sending gold freely into the interior to secure the cotton they required three or four months before it could be available for shipment. This involved an unreasonably long outlay. With the present restriction of credit this will no longer be possible to the same extent, and the culti- vators will require to be content to receive the money value of what they sell only when the cotton is ginned and delivered ready for shipment. The result will be that the culti vators will be unable so speedily to pay their taxes or repay their debts to the Agricultural Bank orto their other creditors. Hitherto, in most cases the cotton-in-seed has not been allowed to leave the farm until the taxes and the debts to the Agricultural Bank were paid, and it may be inexpedient to relax that rule on account of the difficulty of the Treasury to retain an effective lien upon the produce. when it goes to the ginning factory or is in transit to a warehouse in Alexandria.

"But some such measure as the United States Treasury has recently adopted to facilitate the moving of the American crops might advanta geously be imitated by the Egyptian Govern- ment. It might put the National Bank of Egypt (which is to be the State Bank) in funds to make advances on reasonable terms to cultizators against delivery of their cotton-in- seed-these advances to be repaid on arrival of the ginned cotton at Alexandria. The National Bank, unlike most European banks, is organized for such operations; indeed, they are part of its ordinary business; and the Government, possessing in its large reserves first-class securities, could easily obtain the funds requisite from European banks. The advances by the National Bank need in no way interfere with the freedom of commerce, for the cultivator would remain free to negotiate the ultimate sale of his cotton, deliverable two or three months later, on reimbursement of the advances of the National Bank.

"The facilities thus afforded to cultivators would in an important degree lessen the monetary strain upon traders, and, as the drafts of these latter on Europe would then in large measure be against actual shipments of cotton, they would be readily negotiable; in fact they would become drafts accepted by the European banker who received the shipping documents.

"The large shipments of gold from Europe (this year not probably less than seven millions sterling) are necessitated by the fact that the payments to cultivators have to be effected in that metal. Any measure which would tend to lessen the extent of these shipments is deserving of consideration. Fortunately the bank-notes of the National Bank of Egypt are steadily growing in favour with the public, and when their currency is firmly estab lished they may prove a means of partly obviating importations of gold, about half of which are in a few months returned to Europe Tentatively the Government might authorize the National Bank to enlarge temporarily, say during the first six months of the cotton campaign, its issue of bank-notes against approved securities lodged with European State Banks, but without a deposit in gold.

Thus one or two millions of gold might be economized, bank-notes taking their place. If the experiment proved successful it might lead in future years to the diminution by a half of the importations of gold, which now so greatly disturb the money markets of Europe.

"These two suggestions which I venture to make can safely be acted upon by the Egyptian Government, and I think they are worthy of its immediate consideration. Their adoption would be quite in harmony with the enlight ened and paternal solicitude for the interests of the country which has characterized the present régime in Egypt."

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANIES
EGYPT AND SUDAN PROJECTS CORPORATION.
div.p: This concern was registered on the 30th. ult. by Farrar, Porter and Co., 2, Wardrobe- place, Doctors' Commons, E.C., with a capital of £150,000 in 14,925 £10 ordinary shares and 15,000 1/8. The objects are to acquire and develop the business and all or any of the assets and liabilities of the Egypt Sudan Pro- jects Corporation (Gordon, Nassif und Co.), a Société en Commandite, established un- der the law of Egypt, to adopt an agree- ment with the liquidators of the said So- ciété, to acquire and turn to account real and personal property of all kinds in Egypt, the Sudan, and elsewhere, including, particularly, lands, hereditaments, buildings, business under- takings, mortgages, charges, annuities, patents, licenses, shares, stocks, debentures, securities, stock-in-trade, plant, machinery, book debts and claims, and any interest in or benefit of negotia- tions or services relating to any of the fore- going; to develop the resources of land by building, planting, draining, levelling, irrigat- ing, clearing, farming, colonising, stock-raising, timber-growing, mining, quarrying, and other- wise; to promote and assist companies, to own hotels, restaurants, theatres, railways and tramways, &c The signatories are: G J. B. Porter, 2, Wardrobe-place, Doctors' Commons, EC.; E. Mills, 48, Arodene-road, Brixton- hill, S.W; H. I Shaw, Moorgate court, E.C.; R. Berry, 46, Bolingbroke grove, Wands- worth-common, S. W.; C. J. Baker, 43, Lyndhurst-avenue, Streatham-hill, S.W.; C. H. Friday, 26, Hichisson-road, Peckham rye, S.E.; C. W. Farrar, 2, Wardrobe place, E.C. (one share each.) No initial public issue. First directors (not less than three nor more than nine) to be appointed by signatories. Qualification, £500 At least 5 per cent. of the profits is to be carried to reserve fund until such fand amounts to 25 per cent. of the paid-up capital, when the directors may suspend or diminish the contribution thereto. Out of the balance a cumulative preferential dividend up to 6 per cent. is to be paid on the ordinary shares, and 15 per cent. of any surplus still remaining is to be applied as directors' remuneration. Half the residue is to be paid as further dividend on the ordinary shares and half as dividend on the deferred shares.

div.head: THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
div.p: Much indignation is expressed by a con- temporary, upon the Survey Department having resumed the eight hours' day of the winter months. During the summer season, the working hours of this Department are from 7 a m. till 1 p.m. while during the winter they are altered from 8 a.m. until 4 p.m. with a break of half an hour at mid-day. The fact that this is the only Department of the Government in which the staff are called upon to return in the afternoon, or rather almost the only Depart ment, for the Public Works Department work on occasions in much the same way, naturally perhaps, exposes it to adverse criticism, but must not be forgotten that at the time whe first the extra hours of work in the afternoo were introduced, the pay of the whole staff wa increased, in order to compensate it for th extra time.

Any employé who has entered the service o the Department since that time, has done s with a full understanding of what would b required of him. It seems therefore rathe absurd to raise the cry of "tyranny" when th well-known rules of a department are enforced We shall hear next of shopassistants and others who have received a holiday on Sunday, clam ouring for more pay because their master insist upon their returning to work on Monday We should mention too, that during th month of Ramadan, the Mohamedan employe are working, in the Survey. Department as well as others, at reduced hours.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner "City of Venice" sailed from Malta today and is due here with passengers and a general cargo next Saturday evening or Sunday morning early.

The S.S. "Creole Prince," with passenger and general cargo, left Malta on the 9th inst and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday The 8.S. "Imperial Prince" and genera cargo, left London on the 9th inst, and is du to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 26th

div.head: EGYPTIAN AND SUDAN CIVIL SERVICE
SELECTION OF CANDIDATES.
div.p: Mr. E. B. Etherington Smith has issued a note for the Financial Adviser on the constitu- tion of the Board of Selection for candidates for the Egyptian and Sudan Civil Services. The note was drawn up in consequence of a ques- tion asked by Mr. Robertson in the House of Commons on the 25th April Jest to whom it has been transmitted by direction of Bir E. Grey.

The sphere of the Lord's operations are confined within narrow limits, but it is a step in the right direction and the system should be extended to all Ministries and Government Departments. The following is the text of the note?

In 1903 the system was instituted of selecting candidates from the Universities to fill posts under the Egyptian and Sudanese Civil Services. For the first year, while the system was in an experimental stage, a board of selec tion was not formally constituted; a number of candidates were personally, interviewed by the Financial Adviser, and were chosen from among them to pass a probationary year in England. From 1904 onwards the Board of Selection has been composed as follows:-
1904. President, Mr. Vincent Corbett, Fi- nancial Adviser. Members: Lord Edward Cecil, Sudan Agent. P.W. Machell Esq. Adviser to Ministry of Interior. Major Phipps, Civil Se- cretary, Sudan.

1905. President, Sir Vincent Corbett, Fi- nancial Adviser. Members: Sir Reginald Win- gate, Governor-General of Sudan. Capt. Lyons, Director-General of Survey Dpt. Egypt. E. Bonham Carter, Esq, Legal Secretary to Sudan Government.

1906. President, Sir Vincent Corbett, Fi nancial Adviser. Members: A. King Lewis Esq. Controller of Direct Taxes Egypt. Major Phipps, Civil Secretary, Sudan. E. Borus Esq. Director of Agriculture, Sudan.

1907. President, P. W. Machell, C.M.G., Adviser, Ministry of Interior. Members: A. King Lewis Esq. Director-General of Customs Egypt. Major Phipps, Civil Secretary, Sudan. J. W. Crowfoot Esq., Assistant Director of Education, Sudan.

The members of the Board are nominated for one year by the Egyptian and Sudan Governments, each Government appointing two representatives. They receive no salary for their services on the Board. Since 1903 the Board has met 4 times.
The following are the names of the candi- dates who have been selected, and the posts to which they have been appointed :-
1904. Egypt, H. Archer: Inspector, Cairo City Police. N. Macnaughton: Inspector, Ministry of Interior. A. Nation, Inspector, Ministry of Interior. M. Storrs, Secretariat, Ministry of Finance,
1904, Sudan. E. Corbyn, Deputy Inspector, A. Huddlestone, Deputy Inspector, J. Marsden, Deputy Inspector, V. Woodland, Deputy Ins- pector.

1905, Egypt. C. Barton, Assist. Priv. Sec. to Financial Adviser. H. Blomfield, Inspector, Min, of Finance J. Johnson, Inspector, Min. of Interior. A. Loyd, Inspector Min. of Interior. 1905, Sudan. W. Bond, Deputy Inspector, O. Bentley, Deputy Inspector. W. Evans, De- puty Inspector. M. Macdonnell, Deputy Ins pector. H. Macmichael, Deputy Inspector. J Matthew, Deputy Inspector. F. Osborne, De- puty Inspector. C. Willis, Deputy Inspector. 1906. Egypt. R. Furness, Inspector, Alexan dria City Police, H. Hillas, Inspector, Ministry of Finance, E. Hogg, Inspector, Ministry of Finance, F. Teall, Inspector, Cairo City Police, R Wellesley, Inspector, Alexandria City Police.

1906. Sudan. A. Asquith, Deputy Inspector, C. Ball, Deputy Inspector, K. Cornwallis, De puty Inspector, J. Craig, Deputy Inspector, J. Hetherington, Deputy Inspector, T. Leach, e Deputy Inspector, J. Sandford, Deputy Ins pector, C. Scott-Moncrieff, Deputy Inspector. 1907. All on probation in England :- J. Barrow, B. Bell, R. Bence Pembroke, L. Bux-s ton, R. Buxton, S. Davidson, W Forster, H. Jackson, A. Keown-Boyd, A. Holden, P. 9 Munro, W. Nicholls, W. Olphert, A, Pallis, M. Payne.
An interesting ceremony took place last

week at the office of the Russian Imperial Conv sulate, when a captain of the Prince Line, sor familiar to Alexandrians, received a presenta tion from the Tsar of Russia. Last year the steamer "Afghan Prince," of f the Prince Line, conveyed 2,800 Russian solf diers, who had been employed in the war be tween Russia and Japan, from Vladivostock to Odessa. This steamer is under the command of r Captain Mark Campbell, and in appreciation 1 of the personal interest he took in the welfare E of the soldiers, and the care he bestowed on s their comfort during the passage, His Imperial Majesty the Emperor of Russia has deigned to give instructions for the presentation to b Captain Campbell of a gold watch and chain. The presentation was made on the 2nd inst. to Captain Campbell by the Deputy of the Rust
This is the second time that Captain Camp- bell has received a similar mark of Imperial t favour. In 1889 a gold watch and chain was presented to him on the instructions of the
Emperor of Germany, in recognition of his bravery in rescuing the crew of the brigh "Sirius" in the Atlantic.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord and Lady Cromer are staying at Naim for a few weeks.
Mr. Rowlatt, Governor of the National Bank, has returned to Cairo from his holiday.
Mr. H.J.L. Beadnell, FRGS, formerly of the Government Survey Dept and now Manager of the Kharga Oasis for the Corporation of Western Egypt Limited, has returned to Egypt from leave.

The President of France has conferred upon Mr. Theodore M. Davis, of New York, the well-known Bgyptian explorer, the title of Chevalier of the Legion of Honor. The announ cement of this new distinction came by able to Mr. Davis, who is now at Newport.
Mr. Joyce, Sub-Manager of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, at Alexandria, left yesterday for a month's holiday in Italy.
Mr. J.W. Congdon disembarked yesterday at Port Said from S.S. "City of York" and has left for Cairo.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will remain at Montazah until Saturday, when he will come to Ras el Tin Palace.
Borton Bey was received in private audience by the Khedive yesterday on his appointment as Postmaster General.
Sir Vincent Corbett is to be entertained to dinner by the Khedive on the occasion of his retirement.

div.head: A ROYAL VISITOR.
div.p: The King of Siam will arrive at Port Said on the 22nd inst. He will stay in Egypt for about three days during which time he will probably pay a visit to Cairo.

div.head: SIR ELDON GORST.
div.p: On their arrival at Cairo yesterday Sir Eldon Gorst and Mr. Hervey were met by a large number of Egyptian and Sudan Government officials and others, including Saad Pasha Zagloul, Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, Sir Vincent Corbett, Mr. Dunlop, Sir Rudolph von Statin Pasha, Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Scandar Pasha Fahmy, Lord Edward Cecil, and Dr. Graham,

div.head: DEPARTURES FOR EGYPT.
div.p: Sir William Garstin, Adviser to the Mini- stry of Public Works, and Sir Malcolm Moll- wraith, Adviser to the Ministry of Justice, are leaving for Egypt by the P. & O. 9.S. "Macedonia" which is due at Port Said on Tuesday next.
Sir Malcolm Mollwraith was staying at the Hotel Meurice in Paris last week.

div.head: THE RODAH BRIDGE.
div.p: The insinuations of various critics, who have amused themselves from time to time by spreading adverse reports as to the stability of the new Rodah bridge, were effectively answered yesterday, when it successfully withstood the most severe tests to which it was possible to subject it. As a preliminary the foot-paths on either side of the bridge were heaped with sand and rails to the weight of over 1000 tons, but for the various tests which were subse quently carried out under the directions of M. Reimonte, and Mr. Kent, Government Inspec- tors, there were eight steam rollers, twenty tram-cars each leaded with sacks of sand, twenty water, and twenty sand carts, all fully loaded, employed, the total weight of these being 454 tons. The first tests were made by bringing the whole to bear as a dead weight.on each pier sucessively, afterwards distributing the loads in order to obtain an equal pressure upon the main girders of the bridge, on either side of the piers. These tests met with results which were absolutely satisfactory in every respect, not the slightest fault, either in the material or the workmanship presenting it self. Indeed the result was quite exceptional, for the deflexion of girders, invariably allowed for in new bridges did not occur at all. The above experiments occupied the whole of the morning, and on their conclusion the chief resident engineer presided at a most excellent luncheon, catered by the Grand Continental Hotel, in a marquee erected at the month

Further tests were made in the afternoon when the 454 tons above mentioned wasna bodily over the bridge as a "live eight."This trial gave as much satisfaction in fte resu its predecessors had done, and concluded th tests as to the stability and bearing power of

The bridge is, as we have already announced, to be opened as soon as the roads approaching: it are complete and we trust that work in this direction will be vigorously pushed forward. Cairo will have every reason to be proud of her acquisition; it is "a moble atruéfore, nobly built."

Nous regrettons d'avoir constamment à ser- vir au public le même plat, mais en qualité de chroniqueur impartial nous ne pouvrement changer à la réalité des faits Anjourd'hui, domme tous les jours précédents, de note du marché se résume en beaucoup de tapage avec un volume d'affaires limité. A défaut des wa leurs dirigeantes qui, l'Agricole expentée, sont restées négligées, on s'est rahattan sur le groupe en vogne depuis peu de temps, la Cassa di Sconto, le Comptoir et les Nungovich Hotels. Ceux ci ont repris leur mouvement ascensionnel de 17 3/4 à 18.3/8 avec peu de transactions. Il y a eu également de la demande an-Building Lands, Karam et Sucreries et quelques échan res en Levico. Il est intéressant do noter que a Cassa et les Sucreries sont objetos moment d'une poussée simultanée. Nous ver rona bientôt si ce mouvement doit se conso- lider.

Pour la Cassa di Sconto, on prétend qu'elle Honnera de 80 à 90% attraction faite de créances manyaises qui pourront éventuelle ment être récupérées et augmenter d'antant e capital à partager. En prenant les chiffres bi-dessus pour base et en tenant, pompte des Intérêts à courir, pendant 3 ans et des frais de liquidation, on évalue à environ 60 in lavvaleur réelle du titre. On sait que cette bangneun norme portefeuille titres à liquider, et c'est à avantage que lui procure de ce chef la hausse de la cote qu'on attribue en général la pins- value actuelle de la Cassa. Comme il ne nous a pas été possible d'obtenir des chiffres officiels, nous publions naturellement ces données sous coute réserve.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 9 Octobre 1907, à 9 h. p.m. sous la présidence d S.E. le Dr. Schiess Pacha.
Etaient présents; MM. Ahmed Pacha Yehia Escoffier, Mansour Bey Youssef, A. Ralli Soliman Bey Abani et Zervudachi, membres I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire général.
La Délégation renvoie à l'examen de MM Abani Bey et A. Ralli une demande présen tée par M. Comas pour l'établissement d'un bain de mer à Anfouchy.

Elle regrette de ne pouvoir faire droit à une demande de M. Ugo Tedeschi tendant à la location d'une parcelle de terrain de 50.000 m.c. à Chatby pour l'installation d'un tir aux pigeons avec tennis et gymnastique.
La Délégation adjuge à M. V. Di Bari, au prix de 266 Livres Egyptiennes, les travaux de canalisation des rues El Einani et El Imam Aly.
Elle adjuge à MM. Alexandre Papanicolas et Spiridion Calattas, au prix de L.E. 340 par an, la location pour 3 années du café et restau- rant du grand jardin Nouzha.

La fourniture et le montage d'une voie De- cauville au canal Mahmoudieh pour le trans- port des pierres provenant des carrières d'Abou Zabel sont adjugés à MM. Orenstein et Koppel au prix de L.E. 98,600 m/m.

La Délégation renvoie au rapport des servi- ces les nouvelles offres présentées par divers soumissionnaires pour les travaux de confection et de canalisation du prolongement de la rue Sultan Selim en bordure de la mer jusqu'au Palais de Ras el Tin.
Mr. Kempner ayant présenté un tarif pour ses voitures en dehors de la Ville, la Déléga- tion, avant de prendre une décision, renvoie ce tarif à l'examen de MM. Yehia Pacha et Zer- vudachi.

En réponse au rapport de l'Inspecteur Sani- taire de la Ville d'Alexandrie exposant le dan- ger pouvant résulter pour la santé publique, par suite de l'existence du choléra en Russie, de l'arrivée à Alexandrie de pèlerins Boukha- riens se rendant au Hedjaz, Son Excellence le Ministre de l'Intérieur informe qu'il a soumis la question au Conseil Sanitaire, Maritime et Quarantenaire en lui demandant s'il ne serait pas possible d'interdire cette année le passage des pèlerins russes par terre à travers l'Egypte etde les faire transiter directement par le Canal de Suez.
A la suite de cette démarche, le Conseil Sanitaire, Maritime et Quarantenaire a pris, à la date du 1er Octobre 1907, la décision suivante:

"Les pèlerins arrivant à Alexandrie de la Russie, de la Turquie et des Pays Balkaniques pourront débarquer à Alexandrie, mais ils seront envoyés par train quarantenaire à Suez pour de là être embarqués à destination du Hedjaz."

"Cette disposition n'aura d'effet que pen- dant cinq jours à partir du 1er Octobre. Passé ce délai les pèlerins provenant des dites con- trées devront poursuivre directement leur route voie Canal sans communiquer avec l'Egypte." "La liste nominative des passagers arrivant des pays susdits sera dressée pour être remise à l'autorité sanitaire, chargée de leur surveil- lance individuelle."

"L'autorité quarantenaire surveillera les pèlerins du moment de leur débarquement jusqu'à celui de leur installation dans le train quarantenaire; dès lors, les pèlerins seront consignés aux agents de l'Administration Sani- taire et demeureront sous leur surveillance jusqu'à leur embarquement pour le Hedjaz. "Les pélerins arrivant de Port-Saïd seront soumis à des dispositions identiques." La Délégation en prend note.
La Délégation prend note de l'état des recettes et dépenses du 1er Janvier à fin septembre 1907.

Pour le budget ordinaire les recettes ont été de L.E. 187,393 et les dépenses de L.E. 150,470. Pour le budget extraordinaire les recettes sont de L.E. 99,667 comprenant un reliquat de l'exercice 1906 de L.E. 88,222.

Sur ce montant une somme de L.E. 93086 a été engagée par la Commission à fin septembre. 1907, laissant un solde disponible de L.E 6631. Poar ce qui concerne le produit réalisé sur la vente des terrains des quais, les recettes sont de L.E. 86,982 comprenant un reliquat de l'exercice 1906 de L.E. 39,135.
Sur ce montant une somme de L.E. 78,015 a été engagée par la Commission laissant un solde disponible de L.E. 8967.
La séance est levée à 11 h. p.m.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 4 pour cent.

Au Stock-Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de 3/8 à 83 1/8. L'Unifiée a haussé de 1/4 à 102 1/2. La National Bank a été ferme à 22,l'Agricoleà 8 1/2 et la Daïra à 13 7/8. La Delta Light est restée inchangée à 10 1/2. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagné 1 franc à 699. La Banque d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 113. Les Lots Turcs ont baissé de 1 franc à 171.

Ici, la séance a été surtout caractérisée par un manque d'entrain à peu près général dans tous les compartiments. Cela ne veut pas dire que les cours en aient souffert, bien au con- traire, ils sont restés invariés pour la grande majorité, et quelques valeurs même ont accen- tué leur allure haussière, notamment les ban- ques. Beules les affaires ont été calmes, mais eu égard à la saison à peine à son début, il n'y a la rien de bien inquiétant.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na-

tional Bank récupère sa perte d'hier à 22 1/16-1/8. L'Agricole est très active à 8 S.S. La Banque d'Athènes recule à 109-110 et la Ban- que d'Orient à 119-120. La Cassa di Sconto haussé de nouveau à 50-51. Le Comptoir Fi- nancier remonte à 2 15/16-3 et la Société Géné rale Egyptienne se relève à 220 tandis que la part fléchit à 42.

La Delta Light se tasse à 10 3/8. La Daïra Sanieh accuse sa reprise à 13 11/16-3/4. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien se présente à 695-696, son obligation ancienne est en progrès à 303 ainsi que la nouvelle à 254-255.

La Béhéra est recherchée à 21 1/2. L'En- terprise and Development revient à 8 3/4. L'A- gricole du Nil mollit à 193. La Société d'En- treprises et de Travaux est en bonne demande à 3 et sa part est réalisée à P.T. 58-59. L'Union Foncière progresse à 4 3/4 et l'Aboukir à 29/3. Les fondateurs Omnibus-Automobiles semblent mieux disposés à 3 1/2.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Egyptian Hotels (Baebler) se raffermissent à 6 1/16 de même que les Upper Egypt à 3 1/16. Les National Hotelspar contre fléchissent à 2 7/16.
La cote hebdomadaire Le Grelle et Co. (An- vers, Bruxelles et Paris) contient dans son dernier numéro un aperçu fort bien conçu sur les affaires égyptiennes. Nous lui laissons la parole:
"Trois mois se sont écoulés depuis le mo- ment où nous exprimions nos sentiments de confiance dans les entreprises sérieuses en Egypte.

"Dans notre étude de Juillet dernier, nous avons attiré l'attention de nos lecteurs sur le fait que la dépréciation actuelle n'est pas, pour la plupart des titres, l'effet d'un amoindrisse- ment de leur valeur intrinsèque, mais bien. le résultat uniquement de la situation bour- sière.

"Maintenant que très peu de temps encore nous sépare de la reprise effective des affaires en Egypte, nous croyons utile d'attirer une fois de plus l'attention de nos lecteurs sur quelques valeurs de premier ordre, dont les cours, quoi qu'en reprise sur leurs plus basses cotations, laissent encore entrevoir une marge très appréciable vers la hausse.

"Il est très intéressant de constater en pas- sant que les valeurs égyptiennes cotées à Londres n'ont fait que se raffermir depuis leur effondrement de fin Juin et Juillet dernier, alors que tant d'autres valeurs et même des plus solides n'ont pu encore se remettre des assauts violents qu'elles ont en à subir de la part de vendeurs et baissiers pendant le second et le troisième trimestre de cette année.
"Du reste de toute part, les avis qui nous parviennent sont conçus dans une note favo- rable."

On annonce que les groupes belges intéressés dans les affaires égyptiennes auraient décidé d'adopter pour le moment une attitude expec- tante, soit de continuerà développer les affaires existantes, en s'abstenant de nouvelles créa- tions.
D'autre part, on dit que de nouvelles entre- prises belges seraient lancées en Egypte l'hiver prochain, les rapports consulaires belges pour ce pays avant été très favorables.
Pour la semaine au 5 courant, les recettes des "Tramways d'Alexandrie" se sont élevées à L.E. 2,007 contre L.E. 1,781 pour la période correspondante en 1906, soit en augmentation de L.E. 226.
Depuis le 1er Janvier, les recettes totales accusent une plus-value de L.E. 11,796

Pour la semaine au 5 courant les recettes de l' "Alexandria and Ramleh Railways" se sont élevées à L.E. 1,348 contre L.E. 1,279 l'année précédente soit en plus-value de L.E. 69.. Depais le 1er Octobre 1906 les recettes totales montrent une augmentation de L.E. 9,371.

div.head: FRENCH IN MOROCCO.
div.p: Hostile tribesmen have attacked the French force protecting the friendly tribes near Ujda: The French lost four killed or wounded. The tribesmen's losses were heavy. (Reuter)
TANGIER, October 9. A reconnoitring party from Udja was attacked by the Beni Suassen. Two Spahis were killed and wounded. The losses of the Beni Snassen were considerable. (Havas)

div.head: ATLANTA COTTON CONVENTION.
div.p: ATLANTA (Georgia), October 9. The Growing and Handling committee has recommended at the Convention that all cotton should be housed for 40 days be'ore ginning in order to meet the European spinners' com- plaints of dampness which, they say, is not acquired on shipboard, that planters indivi- dually or by communities, should adopt gin- compressing and thus free themselves from the compress trust that they should permit direct handling between the planter and the spinner, that the Egyptian form of bale should be adopted as fast as possible, and that burlap should be used instead of jute. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MACEDONIAN QUESTION.
div.p: The Government, replying to the Austrian and Russian notes, expresses satisfaction at the decision of the Powers to maintain the territorial and political unity of Macedonia, but it insists upon the necessity for defining the limits of the territory in which the reforms will be applied and the administrative division of the country in conformity with the needs of the population. It expresses the desire for the creation of an impartial tribunal for the set- tling of racial, church, and school disputes. It points out the necessity for taking a census of the population, completing the reorganisation of the police, and placing the administration of justice under European control. (Reuter)

div.head: TURCO-PERSIAN DISPUTE.
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE, October 9. Owing to the persistent representations of Sir N. O'Conor the attitude in Turkish quar- ters regarding the Turco-Persian dispute is less uncompromising and there is hope of a satisfactory solution of the difficulty. It is understood that all further advance of the Turkish troops has ceased and that there is a prospect of the evacuation of some points before the meeting of the Turco-Persian com- mission. (Reuter)

div.head: HOME RAILWAY CRISIS.
div.p: Mr. Bell, speaking at the Amalgamated Railway Servants' Conference, said that the Companies having refused to discuss the re- cognition of the Union the only alternative was a row. The Conference passed a resolution supporting the executive's conduct. (Reuter)

div.head: BRIGANDAGE IN PERSIA.
div.p: Russian merchants at Ispahan (Persia) have telegraphed to the "Novoe Vremya" that all roads are in the hands of brigands, that trade is at a standstill, the authorities are supine and the Consuls helpless, and that priests are preaching the boycott of foreign goods. Aid is urgently asked for. (Reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The weekly payments of gold to Egypt have now become the dominating feature of the money market and are likely to continueso until the total gold required for the moving of the crop has been obtained. Last Saturday £700,000 left the Bank for Egypt, and we understand on very good authority that another large ship- ment amounting to between £1,000,000 and £1,200,000, will be made this week-end, for the account of the National, the Crédit Lyon- nais, and the Anglo-Egyptian Banks.

It is interesting to compare the present position with a year ago. In the corresponding week of 1906, or, to be exact, on Oct. 6th. and 7th., no less than £1,600,000 was taken from the Bank for Egypt, which brought the total shipments up till that date to £3,160,000. This year so far only £1,180,000 has been withdrawn for Egypt, so that if the full £1,200,000 is withdrawn to-morrow, the total shipments to date will be £780,000 below last year.

The directors of the Bank of England take an optimistic view of the situation, for, in spite of the fact that the reserve this week has been reduced by two-and-a-half millions, they still retain the Bank rate at 41 per cent. Their con- servative policy appears to be justified, seeing that even now the total reserve stands 5 mil- lions higher than at the corresponding period last year:

The heavy fall in the reserve this week is largely accounted for by the outflow of cash to the country incidental to the end of the quarter. The stock of coin and bullion is lower by £1,662,000, the greater part of which went into the provinces, and there is also an ex- pansion of £741,000 in the active note circula- tion. The decline in the reserve is consequently £2,402,944, bringing the total down to £25,636,000, which compares with last year's total of £20,402,000. The proportion of reserve to liabilities, is 2.44 lower on the week at 48.80 per cent., the proportion in the cor- responding week of 1906 being only 88 per

The quotation for bar gold is unchanged at 77/10. The money market is firm. Yesterday day loans were done at 3 to 3 per cent., seven days' advances realising the latter figure. Three month's discount bills were done at 4 per cent.

The silver market have been weak, owing to the Indian Bazaars re-selling part of their purchases for this week's shipment, as well as offering silver for forward delivery. The cash quotation for bar silver has declined to 30, 11/16.

The only satisfactory feature on the Stock Exchange this week has been the firmness of the markets for gilt-edged and Egyptian securities. In every other department depres- sion has ruled, as the result of a variety of causes-rumours of troubles on the Continental Bourses, the sharp fluctuation in American and Canadian stocks, and the further fall in copper, to mention the chief adverse influences. The strength of first class securities, not- withstanding the harder tendency of the money market, and a considerable reduction in the reserve, is worthy of note, especially when it is remembered that until quite recently this section almost invariably led instead of, as in the present instance, effectually resisting the set-back in other departments.

The rally in Egyptians points to the fact that investors are beginning to realise more clearly the opportunities for lucrative invest- ment presented in the low values of the better class of these shares. With the nearer approach of what promises to be a record season, we may confidently hope that the advance noticeable this week will make substantial progress. To-day markets have been better all round, under the lead of consols.

The gilt-edged market has been very steady, and the list shows a general appreciation in values. At the close last night Consols mark ed a rise on the week of 3/16 at 82. Consols have been buoyant to-day, and have advanced 9/16 for cash and account.

Reported failures in Paris and Amsterdam have operated against foreign bonds, although the tone was slightly more favourable yester day. Japanese issues have been sold, and close lower, further declines of tot being marked last night. Russians gave way in the early par of the week, but yesterday they received some support. At one time the Fives were as good as 881, but later they relapsed, and closed with a loss on the day of at 87 3. The Fours were also down at 75 x. To-day Russian Fours are up . Japanese also show gains of to.

There is nothing new to report regarding the railway crisis. The men's society still await a reply from the Railway Company's Association to the invitation to meet the men's officials in conference in order to discuss the points of difference. As a reply to this invitation is not expected for some days, no developments are likely to take place for the

In the meantime the market for home railway shares continues to mark time, and this week business has again been restricted. There has been some enquiry for stocks in the fixed interest section, but shares in the general list have further declined. Home rails have been rather more in favour to-day, but the changes are few and unimportant.

div.head: YORKSHIRE INSURANCE CO.
div.p: General Agent: F. H. Manley, 3, Rue Cleopatra, Alexandria.

The chief interest in this market has centred in Pacific shares, which have been very excited, owing to a bear "squeeze" in New York. The campaign against the bears sent Canadian Pacific up twelve dollars in Wall Street on Monday. On Tuesday they opened here at 171 or 8 below the parity level, but the bulls tak ing advantage of the spurt, the Quotation fell to 169, closing at 167. Last night they had further receeded to 165.
Unions, which have been up to 132, left off yesterday at 129.
American shares generally have been weak, owing to liquidation from the Continent, and President Roosevelt's series of speeches attack ing the trusts have also had a disturbing influence.
Americans have improved to-day. Canadian pacific have gained 2 and Unions 13.

The tone of the Egyptian market has been quite cheerful, and there has been a renewal of buying orders from good sources for the best securities. Although there was a slight relapse yesterday, in sympathy with other departments, the closing prices showed a substantial increase on the week.

The feature has been the activity of Daira shares, which have commanded much attention. At one time the price of the Deferred rose to 78), as compared with last Friday's quotation of 60-65. To-night they leave off at 68-72. The Ordinary have been quoted 14, but left off yesterday at 13, at which figure they remain to-night. National Banks have been very firm, and have been as high as 227, closing last night at below this figure. They close to-night at 21 15/16-22 1/16.

Yesterday Delta Light Railway Preference were a strong feature, and advanced to 10 which they leave off to-night, showing a rise of on the week. Egyptian Estates have been dealt in fairly freely, and finish at 14/3. The fluctuations in the less important shares have been exceedingly narrow, and on balance prices show scarcely any change.

The reported failures in France and Holland have adversely affected mining shares, and Continental selling has caused the leading speculative favourites to decline. Yesterday there was heavy selling of Tanganyikas, and De Beers Deferred, Tanganyikas being down on the day at 3, which is said to be a fresh low record for these shares this year. De Beers also shed to 20, and Rand Mines 3/82 to 4, 25/32.
To-day mining shares have rallied some- what.
Egyptian mining shares are still unmen- tioned, and close without change.
The closing prices to-night are as follows:

div.head: LAZINESS EXPLAINED.
div.p: Dr. Charles Wardell Stiles, of the United States Pablic Health and Marine Hospital ser Ivice, claims that laziness, or "lazy bug," as it mis called in America, in man is a "branching, proliferating farval worm of the subcutaneous connective tissue of man."
These little creatures bore through the skin, and the patient forthwith becomes an enemy of work of any kind.

div.head: METHODISTS AND WHISKY COCKTAILS
div.p: A telegram from Indianapolis states that Mr. Fairbanks, the Vice-President, who put up as a delegate to the forthcoming Methodist Conference, was yesterday defeated at the meeting of the local Methodists, in con- sequence of having recently ordered and drunk f whisky cocktails at the luncheon, which he gave to President Roosevelt.

Notice is hereby given that, in pursuance of a requisition made by certain shareholders, an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above-named Company will be held in Hall No. 30 at Salisbury House, Finsbury Circus, London, EC., on Thursday the 17th day of October, 1907, at 12 o'clock noon, for the t purpose of considering, and if thonght fit, passing the subjoined resolutions.

(1) Thatit is desirable to adjust the differ- fences between the English and Egyptian Members of the Board as speedily as may be. e (2) That it is desirable to secure again the services of Mr. C.G. Meimarachi as Managing Director in Egypt.

(3) That it be a regulation of the Company prescribed by it in this Meeting that until after d the next Ordinary General Meeting no casual vacancy be filled up by the Directors except by appointment of persons approved by this go Meeting and that Mr. C.G. Meimarachi be approved accordingly.

Holders of the Company's Share Warrants to Bearer wishing to be represented at the above Meeting should deposit their Warrants at the Head Office of the Company, 65, London Wall, London EC., on or before the 14th October, 1907, but for the convenience of Shareholders in Egypt, their Share Warrants may be deposited at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Cairo or Alexandria, on or before the 12th October.
